title: How many books a month should a good reader read? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are all kinds of opinions on how many books people should be reading, as well as what kinds of books they should be reading, and what length of books should be chosen. But I’m here to say that maybe there shouldn’t be a certain ‘formula’ or stigma about how many books you do or don’t read, especially for a certain time frame, like a month. Everyone is different. There isn’t a set formula for how many movies or tv shows or songs we should watch or listen to in a month, and I believe that there shouldn’t be with books, either. It’s different if you have, say, a reading list that you need to complete for school, or a certain number of briefs or emails to read for a job. But let’s say we’re talking about reading purely for enjoyment or your own research. First, for enjoyment:If you want to read for enjoyment, congratulations! You have already committed to the idea of books being fun! Let’s keep it that way, shall we? I’m not going to tell you you should read five or ten or twenty or sixty or ninety books in a month. Because what if you don’t want to read that many? What if you like to soak in what you read, going back over sentences and paragraphs so that you can laugh over them again or simply clarify what you read? What if you want to read more? What if you can’t find that many books that you like? What if you go to the library and none of them are just calling you? (Which I think is a very important part of the reading process, personally.) These are all problems that could occur with anyone trying to find a book to read, along with: MOST PEOPLE WHO READ HAVE A LIFE. You heard me. Just because you’ve made the decision to read doesn’t mean you need to sacrifice your life. In fact, everyone should take that into account! So if you’re someone who literally can only grab a few minutes a week or month to read a book, then so be it. At least you’re reading! So my advice is this: read when you want to. If one month you’d rather binge watch your favorite show whose new season was just put on Netflix, then do that! Reading should not be a laborious process where you’re trying to meet a certain deadline. That’s work! And unless you’re an editor, then reading books is most likely not your job. So don’t make it one. 2. Now, for research or other purposes that aren’t enjoyment: My advice is to divide up the quantity and then divvy it up between the days you can read, and how much you think you can read in a day. If you have ten books you need to read in a month or two, divide them up by pages and which you think will take you the least amount of time to read, and then make sure you read that many pages a day. The point of all of this is that there isn’t a set amount of books or pages or words you should read in a month. There’s only what is right for you.

Read enough books each month to the extent that you can still: Easily comprehend and retain the content without being or feeling rushed as you read the material. If you are filling your time reading Tolstoy and Karamazov, then 1–2 books a month will probably be your max.Have the time to take notes whether it’s in your Moleskine, Evernote, or wherever you keep notes. From The Bonfire of the Vanities, to Great Expectations, to The Great Divorce, to any book by Deming or Don Wheeler, I take notes. This helps me to better understand the content not to mention remembering it. My reading experience is not complete until I’ve finished writing my notes.He doesn’t say it in the clip below, but Charlie “Tremendous” Jones said you will be the same person in five years as you are today except for the people you meet and the books you read.”  I’m confident Mr. Jones would say to slow down (your reading) if you are not getting to know the the author well enough because you cannot comprehend or retain the content. As others have aptly stated, focus on quality, not quantity. The numbers will be what they are. If you are a goal-driven person, then go ahead—add an extra book per month to your reading program. But dial it back if comprehension, retention, and note taking suffers. Listening to Books Still concerned your monthly average book reading is low? I easily get through about 2 Audible books each month. As I write this, I’m listening to Monash: The Outsider Who Won a War, a biography about Australia’s greatest general. That book will knock down my 2-a-month audio books average. Doesn’t matter. I’m meeting a new hero, and I’ve even taken time to read other articles about him across cyberspace. In short, with strategic use of your time, you can nearly double your reading content through audio books. Sidebar | Note Taking and Fiction In case someone asks, I don’t take notes on what I call feel-good pulp fiction. For instance, I did not take notes for The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time (cute book by the way). But for works like Crime and Punishment, Uncle Tom’s Cabin, or The Killer Angels, I took lots of notes.
